I generally look forward to WP's comments here, but this one is quite off the mark. David's column does not "claim that the top 20% in society are a bunch of elite liberals." Such a large group, of course, will have both liberal and conservative members. In that context, David says, "the liberal members of the upper tribe latch onto this top 1 percent narrative because it excuses them from the central role they themselves are playing in driving inequality and unfairness."

And that's a fair point. It's implausible that the top 1% have been solely responsible for creating a global networked economy that produces such an excessive concentration of wealth. That project took teamwork.

I'm well to the left of Obama, but I can see now how my decades as a professional and executive in global business had an unintentional role in constructing just that economy. Guilty as charged.

Wow, is 2012 the year of the bigot for Mr. Brooks? First you write columns praising Rick "Man on Dog" Santorum, a homophobe who made his career advocating for policies that would harm LGBT Americans. Now you are flaunting a book by Charles Murry, the author of the racist screed "The Bell Curve."

As for the substance of your column here, nice try, but it simply doesn't work to claim that the top 20% in society are a bunch of elite liberals. For one thing, voting by the upper classes in the US trends Republican, not Democratic. In 2006, people making over $100k (the top 22% at the time) voted 52-47% Republican, while those making under $100k (the bottom 78%) voted 55-43% Democratic. Similarly, from 1976 to 2004, only 37% of those in the top 1/3 voted Democratic, while 51% of those in the bottom third of income voted Democratic.

In addition, most of the economic inequality is coming from the obscene amounts of wealth collected by the top 1%. This group has the biggest outsized share of income and are the folks who are controlling our political system to such an extent that it is hardly responsive to the needs of the rest of us. Getting the top 1% to start paying their fair share again would be the biggest thing we could do to address economic inequality.

jvnvch: Actually, most people I know hate to fire other people except in the most outrageous situations. They think of them as human beings with obligations. Romney sounded, whether or not he intended to, as if he enjoyed the process.

And yes, I know Romney was talking about firing insurance companies (which is not exactly what he said, but let it pass), but that only means he said something ignorant instead of something offensive. People who get their insurance from their employers are almost NEVER in a position to fire their insurance companies. When their premiums and/or co-pays are jacked up, they suck it up and pay them. Even those with personal health insurance can rarely fire their company, because a) the number of companies has shrunk and the charges and policies of those which remain are virtually identical; b) those who fire their insurance company risk having certain previous illnesses denied coverage; and c) there is always the risk that no other insurance company will cover you at all, if you have a history of actually filing many claims.

In short, Romney's statement showed he has no conception of how the average American lives as far as health insurance is concerned. It may well come back to haunt him in the general election for the wrong reasons, as you note, but it OUGHT to haunt him anyhow.

It is true that highly gifted kids can be misdiagnosed with ADHD because they exhibit some of the same characteristics, such as inattention and excessive activity during school. Like you, they don't need meds, they need higher level material.

But that doesn't mean nobody has ADHD. My son, 15, is highly gifted and has also been diagnosed with ADHD. We spent years rejecting an ADHD diagnosis and trying to address his problems with educational adjustments, parenting strategies, behavior modification. We adamantly refused meds because we couldn't stand the thought of putting our growing child on long-term pharmaceuticals.

But you know what? When we finally agreed, after continuing problems, to try stimulant medication, he was so much more productive, so much happier, and so much better adjusted that it would have felt like child abuse to deprive him of it.

Besides academic functioning, the meds are a huge help to him socially. ADHD is a problem of impulse control, and when a kid can't control his behavior to act age appropriately, he is quickly ostracized. After several years on meds, we tried 3 months without, but we agreed he should go back on because without them he was again alienating his peers, as well as struggling to manage his schoolwork.

Meds don't work magic; we still are constantly trying to teach him strategies and life skills that don't come naturally to him - but I think our struggles would have been harder and our outcome worse without that option.
